item.name: Windows 2008 R2 LogicalDisk Avg. Disk sec/Read
item.description: This measures the average time, in seconds, to read data from the disk. If the number is larger than 25 milliseconds (ms), that means the disk system is experiencing latency when reading from the disk. For mission-critical servers hosting SQL Server® and Exchange Server, the acceptable threshold is much lower, approximately 10 ms. The most logical solution here is to replace the current disk system with a faster disk system.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 LogicalDisk Avg. Disk sec/Write
item.description: This measures the average time, in seconds, it takes to write data to the disk. If the number is larger than 25 ms, the disk system experiences latency when writing to the disk. For mission-critical servers hosting SQL Server and Exchange Server, the acceptable threshold is much lower, approximately 10 ms. The likely solution here is to replace the disk system with a faster disk system.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Memory Available MBytes
item.description: This measures the amount of physical memory, in megabytes, available for running processes. If this value is less than 5 percent of the total physical RAM, that means there is insufficient memory, and that can increase paging activity. To resolve this problem, you should simply add more memory.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Memory Cache Bytes
item.description: This measures the amount of physical memory, in megabytes, available for running processes. If this value is less than 5 percent of the total physical RAM, that means there is insufficient memory, and that can increase paging activity. To resolve this problem, you should simply add more memory.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Memory Free System Page Table Entries
item.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Memory Pages/sec
item.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Memory Pages Input/sec
item.description: This counter includes paging traffic on behalf of the system Cache to access file data for applications. This is the primary counter to observe if you are concerned about excessive memory pressure (that is, thrashing), and the excessive paging that may result. This counter, however, also accounts for such activity as the sequential reading of memory mapped files, whether cached or not. The typical indication of this is when you see high number of Memory: Pages/sec, a "normal" (average, relative to the system being monitored) or high number of Memory: Available Bytes, and a normal or small amount of Paging File: % Usage. In the case of a non-cached memory mapped file, you also see normal or low cache (cache fault) activity.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Network Interface Bytes Received/sec
Windows 2008 R2 Network Interface Bytes Sent/sec
Windows 2008 R2 Network Interface Bytes Total/sec
item.description:
This measures the rate at which bytes are sent and received over each network adapter, including framing characters. The network is saturated if you discover that more than 70 percent of the interface is consumed. For a 100-Mbps NIC, the interface consumed is 8.7MB/sec (100Mbps = 100000kbps = 12.5MB/sec* 70 percent). In a situation like this, you may want to add a faster network card or segment the network.
Use this counter to determine how the network adapter is performing. The Bytes Total/sec counter should report high values, to indicate a large number of successful transmissions. Compare this value with the value reported by the Network Interface\Current Bandwidth counter, reflecting each adapter's bandwidth. If you see the Bytes Total/sec rate approaching the maximum transfer rate, the probability of collisions on the network increases. This in turn impacts performance by increasing the latency of packet transfer on the network. In this case, you might want to consider increasing the bandwidth or segmenting the network. For example, if using 100 megabit/sec fast Ethernet, and the total rate of bytes transferred per second approaches 65 percent of the maximum network bandwidth, you can improve performance by using a gigabit or faster Ethernet switch to segment the network into smaller networks.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Network Interface Output Queue Length
item.description: This measures the length of the output packet queue, in packets. There is network saturation if the value is more than 2. You can address this problem by adding a faster network card or segmenting the network.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 PhysicalDisk % Idle Time
item.description: This measures the percentage of time the disk was idle during the sample interval. If this counter falls below 20 percent, the disk system is saturated. You may consider replacing the current disk system with a faster disk system.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 PhysicalDisk Avg. Disk sec/Read
item.description: This measures the average time, in seconds, to read data from the disk. If the number is larger than 25 milliseconds (ms), that means the disk system is experiencing latency when reading from the disk. For mission-critical servers hosting SQL Server® and Exchange Server, the acceptable threshold is much lower, approximately 10 ms. The most logical solution here is to replace the current disk system with a faster disk system.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 PhysicalDisk Avg. Disk sec/Write
item.description: This measures the average time, in seconds, it takes to write data to the disk. If the number is larger than 25 ms, the disk system experiences latency when writing to the disk. For mission-critical servers hosting SQL Server and Exchange Server, the acceptable threshold is much lower, approximately 10 ms. The likely solution here is to replace the disk system with a faster disk system.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor % Idle Time
item.description: This is the percentage of time the LP is waiting for work for _Total the average percentage across all LP. This is similar to % Kernel Run Time in the Processor counter set.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor % Processor Time
item.description: This measures the percentage of elapsed time the processor spends executing a non-idle thread. If the percentage is greater than 85 percent, the processor is overwhelmed and the server may require a faster processor.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Processor Queue Length
item.description: This indicates the number of threads in the processor queue. The server doesn't have enough processor power if the value is more than two times the number of CPUs for an extended period of time.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Server Work Queues
item.description: Shows the current length of the server work queue for this CPU. A sustained queue length greater than four might indicate processor congestion. This is an instantaneous count, not an average over time.

item.name: Windows 2008 R2 Service Distributed Transaction Coordinator
Windows 2008 R2 Service Group Policy Client
Windows 2008 R2 Service Network List Service
Windows 2008 R2 Service Network Location Awareness
Windows 2008 R2 Service RPC Endpoint Mapper
Windows 2008 R2 Service Security Account Manager

resource.name: Windows 2008 R2 Logical/Physical Disk Read/Write Latency
Windows 2008 R2 Memory Available and Cache
Windows 2008 R2 Memory Pages and Page Inputs
Windows 2008 R2 Memory Free Page Table Entries
Windows 2008 R2 Network Errors NIC Output Queue Length
Windows 2008 R2 Processor and Server Queues

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\Processor Information(_Total)\% Processor Time",300].avg(600,0)}>80
trigger.name: % Total Processor Time

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\LogicalDisk(_Total)\Disk Transfers/sec",300].avg(600,0)}<80 & {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\LogicalDisk(_Total)\Avg. Disk sec/Write",300].avg(600,0)}>0.025
trigger.name: LogicalDisk Transfer Latency

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\LogicalDisk(_Total)\Disk Transfers/sec",300].avg(600,0)}<80 & {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\LogicalDisk(_Total)\Avg. Disk sec/Read",300].avg(600,0)}>0.025
trigger.name: LogicalDisk Transfer Latency

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\Memory\Free System Page Table Entries",300].last(,0)}<10000
trigger.name: Memory Free System Page Table Entries
trigger.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\Memory\Free System Page Table Entries",300].last(,0)}<5000
trigger.name: Memory Free System Page Table Entries
trigger.description: This indicates the number of page table entries not currently in use by the system. If the number is less than 5,000, there may well be a memory leak.

trigger.name: Memory Pages/sec
trigger.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

trigger.name: Memory Pages/sec
trigger.description: This measures the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. If the value is greater than 1,000, as a result of excessive paging, there may be a memory leak.

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\Network Interface(*)\Output Queue Length",300].avg(600,0)}>0
trigger.name: Output Queue Length

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\Server Work Queues(*)\Queue Length",300].avg(600,0)}>7
trigger.name: Server Work Queues

trigger.expression: {Template Windows 2008 R2 Server:perf_counter["\Server Work Queues(*)\Queue Length",300].avg(600,0)}>4
trigger.name: Server Work Queues
